title: 115_hr3804
content: The "Safe Communities Act of 2017" is the short title of this Act. The Congress acknowledges the lack of financial resources for incorporating disaster threats into land use planning, leading to costly relief programs and disruptive security measures. This highlights the need for improved planning to mitigate the impact of disasters and terrorism on communities. The Federal Government should support incorporating disaster mitigation and emergency preparedness into comprehensive land use planning to improve community safety and reduce the costly relief programs and disruptive security measures imposed on United States taxpayers. The Federal Government and State governments should support integrating disaster mitigation and emergency preparedness into land use planning and urban development to reduce post-disaster costs and prioritize prevention strategies. Disaster planning should focus on prevention and incorporate mitigation strategies from various professional fields like urban planning, architecture, and landscape architecture. Comprehensive planning can effectively reduce post-disaster costs and prioritize prevention strategies. Disaster planning should prioritize prevention and incorporate strategies from urban planning, architecture, and landscape architecture. Comprehensive planning can reduce post-disaster costs and enhance prevention efforts. The Federal Government and States should support comprehensive planning for safe communities by providing a conducive statutory environment. Many States lack land use statutes that currently support comprehensive planning for safe communities. Efforts are being made to update state land use statutes to support comprehensive planning for safe communities, including long-term hazard mitigation and emergency preparedness. State and regional investments need to be coordinated with local plans, requiring additional state-level planning. Efforts are being made by many States to update and reform statutes for better planning that incorporates long-term hazard mitigation and emergency preparedness. State and regional investments, including at-risk public infrastructure, need additional State-level planning. Comprehensive urban planning considers the relationship between land use, transportation systems, water and wastewater facilities, open space, and critical infrastructure to promote safe and economically viable communities. Local governments should integrate safety measures. Comprehensive urban planning integrates safety considerations and modern planning techniques to ensure safe housing options for all community members. Safe housing is crucial for safe community development, and comprehensive planning should incorporate modern planning techniques to ensure a variety of safe housing options are available. Prevailing land use patterns can put people, structures, and environmental systems at risk, especially in poorly regulated rural communities and small towns facing significant growth pressures. The Federal Government and State governments should support Tribal governments and Native Hawaiian organizations in implementing land use planning and community development to address growth pressures and haphazard development patterns in rural communities and small towns on the metropolitan fringe. The Federal and State governments should support Tribal governments and Native Hawaiian organizations in implementing land use planning and community development to improve safety and socioeconomic conditions for Indian Tribes and Native Hawaiians. SEC. 3. SAFE COMMUNITIES PLANNING GRANTS. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish a grant program to assist States and local governments in developing or updating land use planning statutes and comprehensive planning documents to mitigate hazards, including acts of terror. The grant program aims to assist States and local governments in updating land use planning statutes and comprehensive planning documents to mitigate natural and human-caused hazards, including acts of terror. The grant program aims to assist States and local governments in updating land use planning statutes and comprehensive planning documents to mitigate natural and human-caused hazards, including acts of terror. The grant program aims to assist States and local governments in updating land use planning statutes and comprehensive planning documents to mitigate natural and human-caused hazards. To be eligible for the grant, a State or local planning director must demonstrate citizen engagement, multi-jurisdictional cooperation, and stakeholder involvement in the planning process. Multi-agency coordination, including cooperation between Federal agencies, is also crucial for effective risk assessment. Implementation elements include a timetable for action, defining roles and responsibilities, and decision-making framework for future infrastructure development. Comprehensive planning encourages incorporating risk assessment and mitigation into land use plans, urban design guidelines, and building codes at the state or local level. Comprehensive planning at the state or local level includes incorporating risk assessment and mitigation into land use plans, urban design guidelines, building codes, and transportation plans. The government also addresses how these plans will be updated over time. The State or local government must update comprehensive plans, including land use plans, urban design guidelines, building codes, and transportation plans over time. Grant funds received must be used for specific purposes outlined in the legislation. Grant funds received by a State or local government must be used for developing comprehensive land use plans, integrating natural hazard mitigation and security plan elements, assessing critical public infrastructure, and mapping for land use and community development policies. The grant funds are used for developing land use plans, integrating hazard mitigation, assessing public infrastructure, and developing geographical information systems. The curr_chunk focuses on developing geographical information systems, scenario planning technology, updating building codes and zoning regulations, implementing CPTED initiatives, assessing risk and vulnerability related to land use, and incorporating mitigation and security elements. The curr_chunk includes reviewing and updating building codes, zoning, land use regulations, implementing CPTED initiatives, assessing risk and vulnerability related to land use, incorporating mitigation and security elements in transportation plans, and encouraging interagency cooperation. The curr_chunk discusses incorporating mitigation and security elements in transportation plans, regional security plans, interagency cooperation, identifying natural hazard areas, and setting a maximum grant amount of $1,125,000. The curr_chunk outlines the integration of natural hazard areas into planning agencies, setting a maximum grant amount of $1,125,000, and specifying a 90 percent federal share for project funding under subsection (a). The integration of natural hazard areas into planning agencies is outlined with a maximum grant amount of $1,125,000. The federal share for project funding shall not exceed 90 percent, with the possibility of an increased federal share for Tribal governments or Native Hawaiian organizations lacking sufficient funds. The Secretary is tasked with encouraging coordination of land use planning for Federal land. The Secretary may increase the federal share of project funding for Tribal governments or Native Hawaiian organizations lacking funds. The Secretary is also responsible for encouraging coordination of land use planning for Federal land with State or local planning directors. The Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security will conduct audits. The Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security will conduct audits on grants provided under this section to ensure funds are used as specified. The Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security will conduct audits on grants to ensure funds are used as specified. Audit results will influence future grant awards to States. Definitions for "land use planning legislation" are provided in this section. Definitions for "land use planning legislation" and "comprehensive plan" are provided in this section. The curr_chunk defines "comprehensive plan" as a document for regulating land use and urban development. A comprehensive plan is a planning document for regulating land use and urban development. The term "State" includes the 50 States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, the Northern Mariana Islands, and Tribal governments. The term "State" encompasses the 50 States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, the Northern Mariana Islands, Tribal governments, and Native Hawaiian organizations as defined in the Small Business Act. The term "State planning director" refers to a State official designated by statute or the chief executive officer of the State. A Native Hawaiian organization is defined in the Small Business Act. The State planning director is a State official responsible for drafting and updating State guide plans regulating land use statewide. The local planning director is a local official designated by statute. The State planning director is responsible for drafting and updating State guide plans regulating land use statewide, while the local planning director is responsible for local comprehensive plans within the local government's jurisdiction. The term "Tribal government" is also defined. The director is a local official responsible for drafting and updating local comprehensive plans regulating land use. Tribal government refers to the Tribal government of an Indian Tribe as defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 4. SAFE COMMUNITIES PLANNING RESEARCH. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct research on best practices in land use and community planning to reduce threats from natural hazards and terrorism. This includes integrating federal facility security with local plans and examining the impacts of security strategies on the community environment. The Secretary of Homeland Security will report to Congress on the integration of federal facility security with local and regional plans, the impacts of security strategies on the community environment, and the integration of mapping and risk-assessment tools. The Secretary of Homeland Security will report to Congress on best practices in community security and safety planning, including evaluations of land use codes, development ordinances, software tools, and risk-assessment strategies. The Secretary of Homeland Security will report to Congress on best practices in community security and safety planning, including evaluations of land use codes, development ordinances, software tools, and risk-assessment strategies, as well as incorporating safety and security into infrastructure planning. The Secretary of Homeland Security will evaluate codes, ordinances, security design standards, and tools for safe residential development. Best practices for incorporating safety and security into infrastructure planning will also be assessed, considering regional, state, and local differences in terms of risk reduction and cost. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2019 through 2023 totaling $57,250,000, with $56,250,000 allocated for grants under section 3 and $300,000 for section 4.
